docs.snippet: LEAD: In an interview here today, the man almost certain to become Mexico's President later this year said repayment of his country's $105 billion foreign debt must be linked to the achievement of ''sustainable economic growth'' and urged the Unit...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: In an interview here today, the man almost certain to become Mexico's President later this year said repayment of his country's $105 billion foreign debt must be linked to the achievement of ''sustainable economic growth'' and urged the United States to seek a more ''dignified'' and realistic relationship with Mexico.

headline.main: Mexican Candidate Ties Repayment Of Foreign Debt to Economic Growth

byline.original: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: In a last-minute concession after two days of difficult bargaining, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua agreed today to open direct talks with rebel leaders and to suspend a state of emergency in Nicaragua....
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: In a last-minute concession after two days of difficult bargaining, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua agreed today to open direct talks with rebel leaders and to suspend a state of emergency in Nicaragua.

headline.main: NICARAGUA AGREES TO TALK DIRECTLY WITH THE CONTRAS

byline.original: By DENIS DONOGHUE; Denis Donoghue holds the Henry James Chair of Letters at New York University, and has published several books of literary criticism. His most recent book is ''Reading America.''

docs.snippet: LEAD: The leaders of five Central American countries opened a final stage of peace negotiations here today amid accusations of bad faith and strongly differing interpretations of the regional treaty they signed five months ago....

headline.main: At Latin Parley, Charges of Bad Faith

byline.original: By JAMES LeMOYNE, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: Leaders of the participating Central American countries at the opening ceremony of a conference yesterday in San Jose, Costa Rica, to judge the results of the regional peace treaty. From the left were Presidents Jose Azcona Hoyo of Honduras,...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Leaders of the participating Central American countries at the opening ceremony of a conference yesterday in San Jose, Costa Rica, to judge the results of the regional peace treaty. From the left were Presidents Jose Azcona Hoyo of Honduras, Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador, Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica, Vinicio Cerezo of Guatemala and Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua.

headline.main: Judgment Stage for Central American Peace Accord

docs.snippet: LEAD: The five Central American presidents who met today in Costa Rica were accompanied by aides and advisers, but the delegation traveling with President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua carried the greatest literary weight....

headline.main: FOR SANDINISTA, A STRONG LITERARY ESCORT

docs.snippet: LEAD: Looking and sounding extremely somber, President Oscar Arias Sanchez said today that the meeting of Central American leaders here Friday will be a ''very difficult'' negotiating session with no guarantee of success....

headline.main: On Eve of the Peace Parley, Costa Rican Is Pessimistic

docs.snippet: LEAD: In a surprise move, President Oscar Arias Sanchez has ordered Nicaraguan contra leaders living here to either resign from the rebel movement or leave Costa Rica....

headline.main: Costa Rica in Ultimatum to Contras
